title: The Dow Slipped 52 Points Because We’ve Already Forgotten the Rate Cut
text:
Text size

The Day After. The main U.S. stock indexes finished the day about flat, following Wednesday’s rate cut by the Federal Reserve. Microsoft stock (ticker: MSFT) gained after declaring its latest buyback plans and a dividend increase. U.S. Steel stock (X) plunged after the company cut guidance. And short-term rental company Airbnb said it’s going public next year. In today’s After the Bell, we...

Moving Cautiously

Stocks closed flat on a quiet day. The Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 52.29 points, or 0.19%, to finish at 27,094.79. The S&P 500 has increased 0.06 points, or 0.00%, to close at 3006.79, and the Nasdaq Composite edged up 5.49 points, or 0.07%, to 8182.88.

The Federal Reserve cut its target interest rate by 25 basis points at the conclusion of its September meeting on Wednesday. The move was largely expected, and investors are now moving their focus to when the next cut—if there is any—will be. The central bank’s latest dot plot suggests no more for this year, but the fed-fund-futures market is still pricing in a 65% probability of at least one more cut in December.

Editor's Choice

Stifel’s head of equity strategy, Barry Bannister, thinks the central bank isn’t being bold enough. Bannister is concerned that the “Fed is willing to play defense instead of offense, and anything they do could end up being too late.” He believes the Fed has already allowed the funds rate to get too close to the neutral rate—one that is neither too tight nor too loose. History tells us, he says, that the closer that rates get to neutral, the closer we are to recession.

One day after the U.S. Fed’s monetary policy statement, global central banks continue to release updates on their own decisions. The Bank of Japan and the Bank of England left rates unchanged, Norway’s Norges Bank tightened earlier than many expected, Taiwan’s central bank lowered rates for the first time in four years, and the Central Bank of Brazil cut its benchmark rates to a record low.

The global economy is now facing many headwinds. On Thursday, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) cut its outlook for global growth in 2019 to 2.9%, the lowest level since 2009 when the global economy was in a deep recession. The Paris-based research body forecast that growth will remain at a low level in 2020 as well.

The OECD noted that if the trade conflict between the U.S. and China spills over into other relationships between the two countries, their economies could be hurt even more.

The OECD cut its growth forecasts for the U.S. and a number of developing economies, including Mexico, Argentina, Brazil, India, Russia, Saudi Arabia, and South Africa. It now expects the U.S. gross domestic product to increase by 2.4% this year, and 2% for the next year, down from May projections for 2.8% and 2.3%, respectively.
